title: Length-Weight Relationship Analysis
text:
This practical exercise demonstrates the analysis of length-weight relationships in fish, using a case study of Snappers (Family Lutjanidae) from Tanzanian coastal waters. Snappers are important demersal fish in Tanzania’s fisheries and exhibit approximately isometric growth, meaning their body shape remains relatively constant as they grow.
The length-weight relationship is described by the equation:
\[W = a \times L^b\]
where:

W = Weight (in grams)
L = Length (in centimeters)
a = Intercept (related to body shape/condition)
b = Slope (scaling exponent, typically ~3 for isometric growth)

This practical exercise demonstrates the analysis of length-weight relationships in fish, using a case study of Snappers (Family Lutjanidae) from Tanzanian coastal waters. Snappers are important demersal fish in Tanzania’s fisheries and exhibit approximately isometric growth, meaning their body shape remains relatively constant as they grow.
The length-weight relationship is described by the equation:
\[W = a \times L^b\]
where:

W = Weight (in grams)
L = Length (in centimeters)
a = Intercept (related to body shape/condition)
b = Slope (scaling exponent, typically ~3 for isometric growth)

title: Length-Weight Relationship Analysis
text:
Objectives

Analyze length-weight data from a Tanzanian marine fish species
Fit a linear regression model to log-transformed data
Visualize the relationship using ggplot2
Extract parameter estimates (a and b)
Interpret biological significance of the results

title: Length-Weight Relationship Analysis
text:
Data Generation
We’ll create realistic length-weight data for Red Snapper (Lutjanus campechanus) caught in Tanzanian waters. For isometric growth, we expect b ≈ 3.

# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(tidyplots)


# Set seed for reproducibility
set.seed(642)

# Generate length-weight data for Red Snapper (isometric growth)
# Parameters based on typical Tanzanian snapper populations

n_samples <- 80

lw_data <- tibble(
  # Length in cm (realistic range for snappers: 15-65 cm)
  length_cm = rnorm(n_samples, mean = 38, sd = 12) %>% 
    pmax(15) %>% pmin(65),  # Constrain to realistic range
  
  # Weight in grams, calculated from isometric relationship
  # For snappers: W = 0.015 * L^3.02 (approximately isometric)
  weight_g = 0.015 * (length_cm ^ 3.02) + rnorm(n_samples, mean = 0, sd = 15)
) %>%
  # Ensure positive weights
  filter(weight_g > 0) %>%
  arrange(length_cm)

title: Length-Weight Relationship Analysis
text:
Linear Regression Analysis
To extract the parameters a and b, we fit a linear model to the log-transformed equation:

lw_data |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = length_cm, y = weight_g)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8, color = "#2E86AB") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, formula = y ~ poly(x, 3), color = "#A23B72", size = 1) +
  # ggpubr::stat_regline_equation() +
  labs(
    title = "Length-Weight Scatter Plot",
    x = "Length (cm)",
    y = "Weight (g)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold")
  )








\[\log(W) = \log(a) + b \times \log(L)\]
This transforms the power-law relationship into a linear relationship suitable for regression analysis.

lw_log = lw_data |> 
  mutate(log_length = log(length_cm),
        log_weight = log(weight_g)) 

fit_lw = lm(log_weight ~ log_length, data = lw_log) # model fitting

y_intercept = coef(fit_lw)[1]
slope = coef(fit_lw)[2]

# Calculating values for a

# log(a) = y_intercept => a = exp(y_intercept)

a = exp(y_intercept) # 0.01080354 
b = slope  # 3.110061


lw_log  |>
  ggplot(aes(x = log_length, y = log_weight)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.6, color = "#2E86AB") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, formula = y ~ x, color = "#A23B72", size = 1) +
  ggpubr::stat_regline_equation() +
  labs(
    title = "Length-Weight Scatter Plot",
    x = "Log of Length",
    y = "Log of Weight"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold")
  )

title: Length-Weight Relationship Analysis
text:
Condition Factor Analysis
The condition factor (K or CF) is a measure of the fish’s health and robustness. It is calculated as:
\[K = \frac{W}{L^b} \times 100\]
where:

W = Weight (in grams)
L = Length (in centimeters)
b = Slope from the length-weight equation (scaling exponent)

The condition factor indicates whether a fish is in good condition (higher values) or poor condition (lower values) relative to its size.

# Calculate condition factor for each fish
k_data <- lw_data %>%
  mutate(
    condition_factor = (weight_g / (length_cm ^ slope)) * 100,
    # Also calculate relative condition factor (K_rel)
    # Expected weight based on regression
    expected_weight = a * (length_cm ^ slope),
    relative_condition = (weight_g / expected_weight) * 100
  )

Visualize how condition factor varies with fish size.

    method = "loess",
    se = TRUE,

title: Length-Weight Relationship Analysis
text:
Summary and Interpretation
The analysis demonstrates several key findings:

Growth Pattern: The slope value (b = 3.11) indicates that the Red Snapper exhibits isometric growth. With b ≈ 3, the fish maintains proportional body shape as it grows, meaning weight increases approximately with the cube of length.
Model Fit: The R² value of 0.9947 indicates that 99.5% of the variation in weight is explained by length. This is typical for biological length-weight relationships.
Parameter Estimates:

a = 0.010804 - This relates to the body condition and shape of the fish
b = 3.1101 - This scaling exponent is close to 3, confirming isometric growth

Fisheries Application: This relationship allows fisheries managers and researchers to:

Estimate biomass from length measurements alone
Monitor changes in population condition over time
Assess growth rates and health status
Convert between length and weight data in stock assessments

title: Daily Egg Production Method (DEPM) - Sample Questions
text:
\[SSB = \frac{P_0 \times A}{R \times S \times F}\]
Where: - SSB = Spawning stock biomass - \(P_0\) = Daily egg production per unit area - \(A\) = Spawning area - \(R\) = Sex ratio (proportion female) - \(S\) = Spawning fraction (proportion spawning per day) - \(F\) = Batch fecundity (eggs per spawning female)

title: Daily Egg Production Method (DEPM) - Sample Questions
text:
Question 1: Basic Calculation
A sardine spawning survey in Tanzanian coastal waters collected the following data:

Daily egg production per unit area (\(P_0\)) = 450 eggs/m²/day
Spawning area (\(A\)) = 5,000 km²
Sex ratio (\(R\)) = 0.52 (52% female)
Spawning fraction (\(S\)) = 0.35 (35% spawn per day)
Batch fecundity (\(F\)) = 12,000 eggs/female

Calculate the spawning stock biomass (SSB).

Answer:
First, convert spawning area to m²: \[A = 5,000 \text{ km}^2 = 5,000 \times 10^6 \text{ m}^2 = 5 \times 10^9 \text{ m}^2\]
Apply DEPM formula: \[SSB = \frac{450 \times 5 \times 10^9}{0.52 \times 0.35 \times 12,000}\]
\[SSB = \frac{2.25 \times 10^{12}}{2,184} = 1.03 \times 10^9 \text{ eggs}\]
Converting to biomass (sardine eggs ~0.75 mg = 0.00075 g per egg): \[1.03 \times 10^9 \text{ eggs} \times 0.00075 \text{ g/egg} = 7.73 \times 10^8 \text{ g}\]
Convert to tonnes (1 tonne = \(10^6\) g): \[\frac{7.73 \times 10^8 \text{ g}}{10^6 \text{ g/tonne}} = 773 \text{ tonnes}\]
\[SSB \approx 773 \text{ tonnes}\]

title: Daily Egg Production Method (DEPM) - Sample Questions
text:
Question 2: Parameter Interpretation
Explain what each parameter in the DEPM formula represents and why it is important for SSB estimation.

Answer:

\(P_0\) (Daily Egg Production): Measures spawning intensity in the survey area. Higher \(P_0\) indicates active spawning; reflects reproductive output per unit spawning habitat.
\(A\) (Spawning Area): Geographic extent of the spawning ground. Larger area = greater total egg production. Accurate delineation is critical.
\(R\) (Sex Ratio): Only females produce eggs. Must adjust for proportion of females in spawning population. Typically 0.48-0.52 depending on species.
\(S\) (Spawning Fraction): Not all females spawn on a given day. Varies by species and environmental conditions. Lower \(S\) = smaller daily fraction of stock spawning.
\(F\) (Batch Fecundity): Individual female reproductive capacity. Higher \(F\) = fewer females needed to produce observed eggs. Critical parameter often determined from histological analysis.

Importance: Each parameter affects SSB inversely or directly. Small errors in any parameter compound to large SSB estimation errors.

title: Daily Egg Production Method (DEPM) - Sample Questions
text:
Question 3: Sensitivity Analysis
If spawning fraction (\(S\)) decreases from 0.40 to 0.25 due to poor environmental conditions, how does this affect SSB estimates? What does this imply biologically?

Answer:
Effect on SSB:
With \(S = 0.40\): Denominator = \(0.52 \times 0.40 \times 12,000 = 2,496\)
With \(S = 0.25\): Denominator = \(0.52 \times 0.25 \times 12,000 = 1,560\)
\[\frac{\text{SSB}_{new}}{\text{SSB}_{old}} = \frac{2,496}{1,560} = 1.60\]
SSB increases by 60% for same number of observed eggs.
Biological Implication:
If fewer females spawn per day (\(S\) decreases), a larger total stock is required to produce the observed daily egg production. This indicates:

Reduced spawning activity per individual female
Possible physiological stress (food scarcity, temperature extremes, pollution)
Recruitment failure or poor condition of females
Need for management intervention (reduced fishing pressure)

title: Daily Egg Production Method (DEPM) - Sample Questions
text:
Question 4: Data Collection Problem
A researcher estimates spawning stock biomass using DEPM but realizes the sex ratio in the spawning population differs from the population overall. How would this bias SSB estimates?

Answer:
Scenario 1: Actual \(R\) > Assumed \(R\)
If more females spawn than assumed: - Denominator is underestimated - SSB estimates are inflated (overestimate of true stock) - Result: More liberal catch recommendations (dangerous)
Scenario 2: Actual \(R\) < Assumed \(R\)
If fewer females spawn than assumed: - Denominator is overestimated - SSB estimates are deflated (underestimate of true stock) - Result: More conservative catch recommendations (safer)
Why This Matters:
Sex ratio bias directly affects SSB by factor of (assumed \(R\) / actual \(R\)). A 10% error in sex ratio causes ~10% error in SSB.
Solution: - Sample spawning ground directly - Use separate sex ratio estimates from spawning area - Conduct sensitivity analysis on \(R\) uncertainty

title: Daily Egg Production Method (DEPM) - Sample Questions
text:
Question 5: Application Question
A small pelagic fishery in Zanzibar wants to set catch limits based on SSB estimates from DEPM. What assumptions must be met for this method to be reliable?

Answer:
Biological Assumptions:

Pelagic eggs: Eggs develop in water column (accessible to sampling). Not suitable for demersal or adhesive eggs.
Defined spawning area: Spawning concentrated in identifiable, accessible location. Not dispersed throughout stock range.
Synchronous spawning: Most females spawn within defined period (season/month).
Steady-state stock: Population not experiencing catastrophic recruitment failure or exceptional year-classes.

Data Assumptions:

Accurate fecundity (\(F\)): Must be determined from gonad analysis of spawning females. Not from historical literature.
Accurate sex ratio (\(R\)): Sampled directly from spawning grounds, not from general population.
Accurate spawning fraction (\(S\)): Requires histological analysis or mark-recapture on spawning ground.
Representative \(P_0\) sampling: Survey must cover entire spawning area, account for spatial patchiness.

Oceanographic Assumptions:

Negligible egg mortality: Assumes eggs survive until next sampling occasion (typically <24 hours).
No egg advection: Spawned eggs remain in survey area (weak currents).

If assumptions violated:

SSB estimates become unreliable
Catch recommendations may be inappropriate
Use sensitivity analysis or combine with other methods (acoustic, VPA, CPUE)

Recommendation: Use DEPM combined with 1-2 other methods for cross-validation.

title: Daily Egg Production Method (DEPM) - Sample Questions
text:
Question 7: Real Data Problem
Given the following data from a Zanzibar anchovy spawning survey:

Survey area: 2,500 km²
Average daily egg production: 320 eggs/m²
Sex ratio: 0.50
Spawning fraction: 0.30
Batch fecundity: 8,500 eggs/female
Survey duration: 5 days
Total catch during survey: 150 tonnes

Calculate:

Spawning stock biomass
Exploitation rate (Catch/SSB)
Is this sustainable? (Assume target exploitation rate = 10%)


Answer:
a) Calculate SSB:
\[SSB = \frac{320 \times 2,500 \times 10^6}{0.50 \times 0.30 \times 8,500}\]
\[SSB = \frac{8 \times 10^{11}}{1,275} = 6.27 \times 10^8 \text{ eggs}\]
Converting to biomass (anchovy eggs ~0.75 mg per egg): \[6.27 \times 10^8 \text{ eggs} \times 0.00075 \text{ g/egg} = 4.70 \times 10^8 \text{ g} = 470 \text{ tonnes}\]
SSB = 470 tonnes
b) Exploitation Rate:
\[E = \frac{\text{Catch}}{\text{SSB}} = \frac{150}{470} = 0.319 = 31.9\%\]
c) Sustainability Assessment:

Current exploitation: 31.9%
Target exploitation: 10%
Conclusion: Stock is overexploited at current fishing pressure. Catch should be reduced to ~47 tonnes to meet the 10% target exploitation rate
This indicates unsustainable harvest levels and need for management intervention

Key Equations

Logistic growth: \[\frac{dN}{dt} = rN\left(1 - \frac{N}{K}\right)\]

Ricker recruitment: \[R_t = aS_t e^{-bS_t}\]

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Fish abundance

Fish abundance refers to the number of individuals in a fish population within a defined area.
It is a key metric for assessing the health and sustainability of fish stocks.
Accurate abundance estimates inform management decisions, such as setting catch limits and conservation measures.
Abundance can be expressed as:

Absolute abundance – Measure the actual number of fish in an area i.e Pond
Relative abundance – Estimate the number of fish at a given locality

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Fish abundance…

Abundance is not a fixed quantity – Varies from time to time (seasonal) due to;

Internal forces i.e births and deaths and
External forces i.e seasonal availability of food, changes in environmental conditions that may affect the population

It varies from place to place because of the heterogeneity of the environment

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Fish abundance…

Within the area of distribution the abundance of a population always vary – either grow (increase) or decline
The population may vary with season due to;

Births
Deaths

Seasonal migration (spawning, feeding and over-wintering) recruitment

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Fish migration

Fish migration is mass relocation by fish from one area or body of water to another.
Fish migrate;

On a regular basis

On time scales – from daily, seasonal, annually or

Longer, and over distances – from a few metres to thousands of kilometres.

Such migrations are usually done for feeding or to reproduce, but in other cases the reasons are unclear.
Migration affects local abundance estimates and must be considered in survey design.

Terminologies in fish migration

Diadromous – Fishes that migrate between the sea and freshwater.
Anadromous – Diadromous fishes which spend most of their lives in the sea and migrate to freshwater to breed (salmon, sea trout, shad, sea lampreys, sturgeons)
Catadromous – Diadromous fishes which spend most of their lives in freshwater and migrate to the sea to breed (eel, Salangidae, Galaxidae, Retropinnidae).
Amphidromous – Diadromous fishes which migrate from the sea to freshwater or vice versa, but not for the purpose of breeding (some Exocidae,Perca fluviatilis, some Mugilidae).

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment

Terminologies in fish migration…

Potamodromous – Migratory fishes that live and migrate wholly within freshwater systems (rivers, lakes, streams). They never enter marine environments e.g (trout, bream, Coregonoids)

Complete their entire life cycle in freshwater.
Migrate between different freshwater habitats for spawning, feeding, or overwintering

Their migration patterns are triggered by Water temperature changes, Flooding (access to floodplain habitats), Photoperiod (day length), Food availability, Spawning readiness

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Terminologies in fish migration…

Oceanodromous – Migratory fishes that live and migrate wholly within the sea (marine environment). They never enter freshwater. (cod, herring, capelin, tuna, mackerel).
Complete their entire life cycle in marine waters
Migrate between different ocean habitats for spawning, feeding, or seasonal movements
Migration distances can range from coastal movements to trans-oceanic journeys (thousands of kilometers)
Their migration patterns are triggered by Sea surface temperature gradients, Ocean current patterns (monsoons in Indian Ocean), Prey availability (following zooplankton blooms), Spawning readiness and lunar cycles, Upwelling events

Exponential Growth Model

The Exponential Growth Model describes population growth when there are no resource limitations.
It assumes that the population grows at a constant rate, leading to exponential increase over time.

Formula:
\[N_t = N_0 e^{rt}\]
Or equivalently:
\[N_t = N_0 \lambda^t\]


Where:

\(N_t\) = population size at time t
\(N_0\) = initial population size
\(r\) = intrinsic rate of increase (growth rate)
\(\lambda\) = population growth rate
\(t\) = time


What it means:

If \(r > 0\): population grows exponentially
If \(r = 0\): population stable
If \(r < 0\): population declines or shrink

Data used in stock assessments

Data for fish stock assessments falls into two main categories:


Fishery-dependent data
Fishery-independent data

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Fishery-Dependent Data
Overview
Fishery-dependent data comes directly from the fishing process itself. Common sources include:

Self-reporting by fishers
Onboard observers accompanying fishing vessels
Portside surveys and sampling
Telephone surveys
Vessel-monitoring systems

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Fishery-Independent Data
Overview
Fishery-independent data comes from research activities that do not involve harvesting fish. These include:

Research surveys using standardized gear (trawls, seines, acoustic, video, and side-scan sonar)
Tagging experiments
Acoustic surveys to detect fish abundance using specialized detectors

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Data Requirements for Stock Assessments
Successful stock assessments require three key types of data:

Catch data – information on harvested fish
Relative abundance data – indices of stock size
Life history data – species’s age, growth, and maturity information

Both fishery-dependent and fishery-independent data sources contribute to meeting these requirements.

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Landing Records
Landing records are among the most common fishery-dependent data sources:

Records result directly from the sale of caught fish at ports
Typically provide information on landed catch only
Usually recorded as total weight rather than number of individual fish
Often supplemented by port samples for biological information

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Portside Sampling
Definition and purpose
Portside sampling involves collecting biological data from a portion of the catch at landing sites:

Conducted by government scientists called portside observers or port agents
Samples are measured for size and age information
For recreational fisheries, this is referred to as a creel survey

Data collection methods

Fish size is measured directly at the dock
Age is determined by counting growth rings in fish scales or otoliths (ear bones), similar to counting tree rings

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Onboard Observers
Purpose
Onboard observers are government personnel who accompany commercial fishing vessels to:

Monitor how fishermen interact with target and non-target species
Collect detailed information about catch composition

Data collected

Sample catch for size and age information
Estimate bycatch (incidental catches of non-target species)
Estimate discards (fish returned to the sea)

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
section: Log Books and Vessel Trip Reports
text:
Log Books and Vessel Trip Reports
Overview
Fishermen may be required or encouraged to keep their own records:

Log books and vessel trip reports document fishing activities
Maintained either as mandatory requirement or organized voluntary effort

Reliability and applications

Less reliable than landing records and onboard observer data for estimating catch weight and numbers
Valuable for determining spatial distribution of fishing effort
Useful for tracking fishing effort across seasons and areas
Some fisheries use vessel monitoring systems (VMS) – electronic devices that automatically record vessel location and movements

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Telephone Surveys

Primary method for collecting data on recreational fisheries
Also widely used for small-scale fisheries to record catch numbers, location, and size information
Provides complementary data when on-site sampling is impractical

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Research Survey Approaches

Research surveys provide data independent of fishing activities
Scientists use standardized sampling gear: trawls, seines, hydroacoustics, and video
Samples are collected throughout the potential range of target fish

Survey Flexibility

Can target multiple species or focus on a single species
Can target specific life stages (e.g., juvenile year classes)

Data Benefits

Provide abundance indices for stock assessment
Collect size, age, and maturity information from the stock

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Mark and Recapture Studies

A specialized research method for estimating population parameters
Provides estimates of:

Fish movement and migration patterns
Growth rates
Natural mortality
Discard mortality

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Fisheries Frame Survey
Definition

A census-based approach that collects data on all fishing vessels and gear types
Covers all homeports and fishing sites within the assessment area

Supplementary Information

Fishing trip patterns and frequency
Seasonal patterns of gear use
Socio-economic information about fishing communities
Demographic profiles of fishers

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Frame Survey Data Collection
Landing Site and Fleet Information

Number of operational fish landing sites
Number of active fishers
Number and types of fishing crafts
Modes of propulsion (motorized, manual)

Facilities and Services

Infrastructure available at landing sites
Services provided by fisheries staff
Support from Beach Management Units (BMUs)

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Frame Survey Data Collection (continued)
Gear Information

Types and sizes of fishing gears in use
Operation modes for different gear types

Management Applications

Recommendations for fishery development and management
Raising factors for extrapolating Catch Assessment Survey (CAS) data to total catch estimates

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Frame Survey Implementation
Staffing Requirements

Often requires many data collectors
May employ temporary staff to supplement regular fisheries personnel

Training and Instructions

Data collectors must receive precise, unambiguous instructions
Critical for ensuring data reliability
Detailed training on recording forms and their proper use
Clear explanation of each form’s purpose within the overall programme

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
section: Frame Survey Planning and Quality Assurance
text:
Frame Survey Planning and Quality Assurance
Survey Design

Clarify categories for boat and gear types
Define sequential vs. concurrent gear use
Identify whether new gear types should be included

Field Operations

Plan visits to all landing ports
Develop protocols for approaching and interviewing fishers and village leaders
Ensure comprehensive information on vessel and gear numbers

Quality Control

Implement cross-checking procedures for collected data
Establish protocols for addressing serious discrepancies

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Limitations of Frame Surveys
Temporal Snapshot

Provide static information valid only at the time of the survey
Represent a single snapshot of the fishery

Impact of Changes

Rapid changes to the fishery compromise accuracy:

Changes in number of fishing boats
Introduction of new fishing gear types
Shifts in fishing effort or patterns

Such changes make raising factors unreliable for estimating total effort

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
section: Data Integration in Fish Stock Assessment
text:
Data Integration in Fish Stock Assessment
Key Data Components

Fisheries Statistics – catch and effort data
Frame Survey Data – fleet and gear information
Biological Data – from research surveys and port sampling

Application

These data are integrated to develop predictive models
Models assess current stock status under various conditions
Enable managers to evaluate impacts of different management strategies

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Catch Assessment Surveys
What is a CAS?

Survey designed to estimate total catch from a fishery
Based on sampling a portion of landing sites or fishing effort

Why CAS Matters

Bridges gap between complete census (infeasible) and incomplete data
Provides reliable catch estimates with quantified uncertainty
Essential for ecosystem-based management
Supports accurate monitoring of harvest levels

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
CAS vs. Frame Surveys
Frame Survey

Census of all fishing vessels and gear
Provides information on fishing infrastructure and capacity

Catch Assessment Survey

Sampling of catch from selected landing sites or vessels
Collects biological and quantitative catch data
Uses frame survey raising factors to estimate total catch

Integration

Frame survey defines population and provides raising factors
CAS provides representative sample of actual catches
Together produce robust total catch estimates
Uses raising factors from frame surveys to scale up sample data to population level
Generates raising factors for expansion to total population

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
CAS Data Collection
Information Recorded

Total catch weight by species and gear type
Length and age composition of catch
Sex and maturity information from samples
Bycatch and discards estimates
Date, location, and gear type for each sample

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
CAS Data Collection…
Raising Factor Calculation
Raising Factor = Total boats/gear from frame survey ÷ Sampled boats/gear
Example

Frame survey identifies 100 fishing boats at a landing site
CAS samples 20 boats’ catch
Raising factor = 100 ÷ 20 = 5
Sample catch × 5 = Estimate of total catch from all boats

Introduction to population dynamics
What is population?

A population is a group of individuals of the same species that live together in a particular area
A fish population is a group of fish of the same species that live in a particular area.

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Introduction to population dynamics

Fish population dynamics describes the ways in which a given fishery population grows and shrinks over time, as controlled by birth, death, and migration
It is a basis for understanding changes of fishery patterns and issues such as habitat destruction, predation and optimal harvesting rates
The population dynamics of fisheries is used by fisheries scientists to determine sustainable yields.

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Introduction to population dynamics

Population dynamics is a branch of life science dealing with the short and long-term changes in the size and age composition of populations, and the biological and environmental processes influencing those changes.
It deals with the way populations are affected by birth and death rates, and by immigration and emigration.

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Introduction to Stock assessment

Stock assessment is examination of development of fish stock using mathematical and statistical models to make quantitative predictions in order to address fisheries management issues.
Stock assessment is the process of collecting and analyzing demographic information about fish populations in order to describe the conditions or status of fish stock

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Aim of stock assessment

Assessment of the current state of stock
Assessment of the past stock situation
Predictions to the future stock based on management choices
An estimation of the rate at which it is being removed due to harvesting etc.

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Aim of stock assessment…

Stock assessment describe a range of life history characteristics for a given species

It includes age, growth, natural mortality, sexual maturity and reproduction, stock boundaries, diet preferences, habitat characteristics, species interactions, and environmental factors that may affect the species

Assessment also include descriptions of the fishery for a species, using information from both scientists and fishermen

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Definition of key terms

Fish Catch is the total number or weight of fish captured from an area over a period of time.
This includes fish that are caught but released or discarded instead of being landed.
Carrying Capacity is amount of fish that a specific habitat can support.
Bycatch is the harvest of fish or animals other than the species for which the fishing gear was intended

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Definition of key terms…

Catch Per Unit Effort (CPUE) is the quantity of fish caught (in number or in weight) with one standard unit of fishing effort.
Effort can be number of fishing gear or vessel, length of time used during fishing, number of fishermen etc.
e.g. number of fish taken per 1000 hooks per day or weight of fish taken per hour of trawling.
CPUE is often considered as an index of fish biomass (or abundance).
CPUE is also referred to as catch rate

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Definition of key terms…

Effort is the amount of time and fishing power used to harvest fish.
Fishing power includes gear size, boat size, and horsepower.
Fish Density is the number of fish per unit area.
Spawning the number of eggs and sperm released into water by fish.
Spawning rate is the number of eggs and sperm released per unit time

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Definition of key terms…

Cohort is a group of fish spawned during a given period, usually within a year
Recruitment the number of new young fish that enter a population in a given year.
Morphometrics these are measurements which characterize the form, shape and appearance of a fish.
Difference in morphometrics, such as colouration, can be used to distinguish different stocks of the same species.

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Definition of key terms…

Maximum sustainable yield (MSY) is theoretical harvest of a fish species that can be taken over an indefinite period.
MSY theoretically aims to maintain the population size at the point of maximum growth rate by harvesting the individuals that would normally be added to the population.
MSY has been widely criticized and has led to the collapse of many fisheries, as it ignores size, age, reproductive capacity, and fishing effort.

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Definition of key terms…

Fish mortality is a parameter that account for the loss of fish in a fish stock through death.
The mortality can be divided into two types;

Natural mortality – the removal of fish from stock due to causes not associated with fishing.
Such causes can include disease, competition, cannibalism, old age, predation, pollution or any other natural factor that causes the death of fish.
In fisheries models natural mortality is denoted by (M)

title: AQ 232 – Fish population dynamics and stock assessment
text:
Definition of key terms…

Fishing mortality – the removal of fish from stock due to fishing activities using any fishing gear.
It is denoted by (F) in fisheries models.
Mortality rate or death rate is a measure of the number of deaths in a particular population per unit time.
Mortality rate is the rate at which fish die, typically shown as a percentage.
Survival rate is a measure of number of alive fishes in a particular population per unit time

Fecundity is the number of eggs or offsprings produced by fish during the spawning season.

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
What are Vital Rates?



Vital rates are the key demographic parameters that determine how a population changes over time.
The three main vital rates:


Recruitment: Addition of new fish to population
Growth: Increase in size/weight over time
Mortality: Deaths in the population


Together they determine:

Population growth rate
Sustainable harvest level
Recovery potential

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Why Vital Rates matter?

Together, they determine whether a population grows, stays stable, or declines
They are the foundation for all population models and harvest decisions
Understanding and measuring them is essential for stock assessment

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Vital rates equation
Population change Equation: How Vital Rates work together
\[N_{t+1} = N_t + R_t - M_t - C_t\]
What each term means:

\(N_{t+1}\) = Population next year
\(N_t\) = Current population
\(R_t\) = Recruitment (new fish added)
\(M_t\) = Mortality (natural deaths)
\(C_t\) = Catch (fishing removals)

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Understanding the Equation
Interpretation:
Next year’s population = This year’s fish + New recruits - Deaths from disease/predation - Fish caught by fishers
Example:

Start with 10,000 fish
Add 3,000 recruits
Lose 1,500 to natural causes
Remove 2,000 by fishing
Result: 10,000 + 3,000 - 1,500 - 2,000 = 9,500 fish next year

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Recruitment (R)
Recruitment: – The addition of new fish to the population through reproduction and settlement of larvae/juveniles
Recruitment process:
Adult fish spawn → Eggs released → 
Eggs hatch → Larvae drift → Settlement → 
Juveniles enter fishery

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Recruitment (R)…


Key Characteristics:

Highly variable year-to-year
Depends on spawner abundance
Environmental conditions critical
Early life-stage survival crucial


Why Recruitment is hard to predict?:

Millions of eggs produced
Few survive to catchable size
Environmental variation huge
Density-dependent effects

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Growth (G)
Growth: – The increase in size and weight of individual fish as they age
Growth Pattern:

Fastest when young (more energy to growth)
Slows with age (more energy to reproduction)
Asymptotic (approaches maximum)
Affected by environment and density

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Growth (G)…
Von Bertalanffy Growth Model:
\[L_t = L_\infty(1 - e^{-K(t-t_0)})\]
Where:

\(L_t\) = Length at age t (what we are trying to predict)
\(L_\infty\) = Length at infinity – Asymptotic length (maximum length fish can theoretically reach)
\(K\) = Growth rate coefficient (how fast fish approach maximum length)
\(t = Age\)
\(t_0\) = Theoretical age at zero length (usually close to 0)

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Logic Behind Von Bertalanffy Model
The Biology:

Fish grow fastest when young - At age 0, the term \((1 - e^{-K(t-t_0)})\) is close to 0, so length is small
Growth slows with age - As fish get older, they approach \(L_\infty\) asymptotically (get closer to the maximum length but never quite reach it)
Approaches a maximum - No matter how old the fish gets, it cannot exceed \(L_\infty\)
Growth rate controlled by K - A larger \(K\) = fish reach maximum size faster; smaller \(K\) = slower growth

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Why Von Bertalanffy Model realistic?

Fish actually DO grow quickly early and slow down with age
Energy allocation shifts from growth to reproduction
Food becomes limiting relative to body size

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Real-World Example: Atlantic Cod
Growth Parameters for Atlantic Cod:

\(L_\infty = 120\) cm (maximum size)
\(K = 0.1\) per year (growth rate)
\(t_0 ≈ 0\) (age at zero length)

Predicted Lengths at Different Ages:

Age 5: \(L_5 = 120(1 - e^{-0.1(5)}) ≈ 47\) cm
Age 10: \(L_{10} = 120(1 - e^{-0.1(10)}) ≈ 76\) cm
Age 20: \(L_{20} = 120(1 - e^{-0.1(20)}) ≈ 104\) cm
Age 50: \(L_{50} = 120(1 - e^{-0.1(50)}) ≈ 119\) cm (approaches maximum)

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Real-World Example: Atlantic Cod…
Management insight:

Young cod (age 5-10) grow rapidly and can be caught sustainably
Old cod (age 20+) are larger and valuable but grow slowly

section: Real-World Example: Nile Perch in Lake Victoria
text:
Real-World Example: Nile Perch in Lake Victoria
Growth Parameters for Nile Perch (Lates niloticus):

\(L_\infty = 200\) cm (maximum size - can reach very large)
\(K = 0.08\) per year (relatively slow growth rate)
\(t_0 ≈ 0\) (age at zero length)

Predicted Lengths at Different Ages:

Age 5: \(L_5 = 200(1 - e^{-0.08(5)}) ≈ 66\) cm
Age 10: \(L_{10} = 200(1 - e^{-0.08(10)}) ≈ 110\) cm
Age 15: \(L_{15} = 200(1 - e^{-0.08(15)}) ≈ 140\) cm
Age 20: \(L_{20} = 200(1 - e^{-0.08(20)}) ≈ 160\) cm
Age 30: \(L_{30} = 200(1 - e^{-0.08(30)}) ≈ 182\) cm

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Nile Perch: Management Implications
Lake Victoria Fishery Context:

Young Nile Perch (5-10 years) - 60-107 cm, increasingly valuable for export market
Prime fish (15-20 years) - 140-165 cm, highest commercial value, very slow growth
Old fish (30+ years) - Over 185 cm, rare due to fishing pressure

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Nile Perch: Management Implications…
Growth Trade-off Problem:

Takes 15+ years to reach prime commercial size
Takes 25+ years to reach maximum size
Slow growth rate (\(K = 0.08\)) means population recovery is slow

Stock Collapse Risk:

If fishing pressure targets large valuable fish, population structure becomes skewed to small fish
Loss of old fish eliminates spawners with highest fecundity
Overfishing compounds slow growth → stock cannot recover quickly
Lake Victoria Nile Perch catch has been declining since 1990s

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Introduction

Fish stock assessment was developed in the temperate regions where there are very few species of fish.
It was based on a single species
However, such a consideration is not very applicable for tropical fisheries where we have multi-species fisheries because;

Different species are mixed up
There is very high interaction among species

In such situation, fish populations are divided into stocks (unit stock) for management and assessment purposes
Understanding the distribution, abundance, and methods for estimating stock parameters is important for effective stock assessment and sustainable fisheries management.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Unit Stock

A unit stock is a population of fish, either of a single or different species, grouped together for assessment purposes which may or may not include all the fish in a stock.
A unit stock is a group of fish that:

Share a common gene pool – can interbreed
Occupy a defined geographical area – have a specific distribution
Exhibit similar life history traits – growth, reproduction, mortality
Are subject to similar fishing pressures – exploited by the same fisheries
Are managed as a single entity – for conservation and exploitation, – Can be managed independently from other stocks

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Determination of a Unit Stock

Unit stocks can be determined through various biological and ecological characteristics, including:

Distribution patterns – Where unit stocks are located
Spawning behavior – Different stocks spawn in different areas
Population parameters – Recruitment, growth and mortality rates, morphometric differences
Physiological traits – Temperature at hatching, vertebrae structure, scale decorations, parasite types

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Distribution and Abundance
Geographic Distribution

Geographic distribution refers to the spatial area where a fish stock is found, including the boundaries of its range.

Key concepts:

Fish populations are not uniformly distributed across all suitable habitats
Distribution patterns change seasonally (spawning, feeding, wintering areas)
Some species have discrete distributions while others have overlapping ranges
Distribution limits are determined by temperature, salinity, bathymetry, and food availability

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Geographic Distribution
Examples:

Migratory species (salmon) move between coastal and riverine habitats
Demersal species (bottom-dwelling) have specific depth distributions
Pelagic species distribute widely in open water

Management implications:

Fishing effort should target areas of highest concentration
Seasonal closures may protect aggregations during vulnerable periods
International boundaries may complicate management of stocks crossing borders

Spatial and Temporal Variation in Abundance
Temporal Variation:

Seasonal changes - Abundance fluctuates with feeding, spawning, and migration cycles
Interannual variation - Year-to-year changes in recruitment and survival
Long-term trends - Decadal-scale changes related to fishing pressure or environmental conditions

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:

Spatial Variation:

Patchiness - Fish concentrate in certain areas (spawning grounds, feeding areas)
Gradients - Density changes across depth, latitude, or habitat types
Hotspots - Areas of consistently high abundance

Substrate type - Bottom type affects benthic food availability

Physical Oceanography:

Coastal current patterns structure population distributions

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment

Environmental Influences…
Climate and Weather:

Seasonal weather events (storms, cold snaps) cause temporary distribution changes

Straddling stock and highly migratory fish stock

With 1982’s United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), coastal nations were given the right to manage fisheries within their Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ)
But of course, fish don’t adhere to imaginary lines in the ocean.
The management of two groups – straddling and highly migratory fish stocks became problem after the 1982 Convention.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Straddling stock

Straddling stocks are fish stocks that migrate across more than one Exclusive Economic Exclusion Zone (EEZ) and the high seas

Straddling stocks is the stocks of fish which migrate between, or occur in both, the EEZ of one or more states and the high seas

Fish stocks that migrate through, or occur in more than one exclusive economic zone.
They include species such as swordfish and marlin.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Highly migratory fishes

Highly migratory fishes are the ones that travel long distances across international waters
These include tuna and tuna-like species such as yellowfin tuna, bigeye tuna, and skipjack.

text:
Management of Straddling stock and Highly migratory fishes

Management of the straddling stock and highly migratory fishes is a shared responsibility between coastal states and the international community.
The 1995 United Nations Fish Stocks Agreement (UNFSA), an international treaty designed to further implement provisions of the 1982 Convention which;

Ensure the long-term conservation and sustainable use of straddling fish stocks and highly migratory fish stocks

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Mixed stock

A mixed stock occurs when individuals from two or more genetically distinct populations are found together in the same geographic area
Fish from multiple spawning populations intermingle during feeding, migration, or overwintering
Cannot be easily distinguished visually but are genetically or demographically separate

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Common Scenarios for Mixed Stock
1. Feeding Aggregations

Fish from different spawning stocks congregate in productive feeding grounds
Example: Salmon from multiple rivers feeding together in the ocean

2. Migratory Overlap

Different populations share migration routes
Example: Tuna stocks from different ocean regions mixing along migration corridors

3. Seasonal Mixing

Populations separate for spawning but mix at other times
Example: Herring from different spawning grounds overwintering together

text:
2. Acoustic Surveys

The hydroacoustic survey uses an echo sounder to conduct acoustic biomass estimation.
It is widely used for assessing pelagic fish stocks (e.g., sardines, anchovies, herring, mackerel, tuna).

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
2. Acoustic Surveys

In practice for fish stock assessment, acoustic surveys are used to estimate fish stock.
These surveys are used to estimate the abundance of fish species that form schools in the water column.
They are particularly useful for pelagic species that are difficult to sample with traditional trawl surveys.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Acoustic Surveys: Key Terms

Acoustic survey - A survey that uses acoustic sound to estimate fish stock.
Echo sounder - A device that uses sound waves to detect fish.
Echo - A sound wave that is reflected back to the sounder.
Hydroacoustic survey - A survey that uses hydroacoustic sound to estimate fish stock.
Hydroacoustic means using sound in water.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Acoustic survey methodology

An acoustic transducer emits a brief, focused pulse of sound into the water.
If the sound encounters objects that are of different density than the surrounding medium, such as fish, they reflect some sound back toward the source.
The time it takes for the echo to return is used to calculate the distance to the object.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Acoustic survey methodology…

These echoes provide information on fish size, location, and abundance.
The basic components of the scientific echo sounder hardware function is to transmit the sound, receive, filter and amplify, record, and analyze the echoes.
While there are many manufacturers of commercially available fish-finders, quantitative analysis requires that measurements be made with calibrated echo sounder equipment, having high signal-to-noise ratios.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Principle of echo sounding

Everything scattered in the water column reflects sound waves depending on the frequency of the waves.
The higher frequency the shorter the wave length.
Therefore frequencies > 200 KHz can produce echo from plankton.
For fishes, a lower frequency < 200 KHz is used

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Conditions for echo sounding

Suitable for small pelagic fish stocks (big pelagic fishes eg. Tuna swim very fast and therefore the method becomes unsuitable).
The behavior of the fish to be assessed must be known

e.g the distribution of the fish in the water column at different times
The reaction of the fish towards the fishing boat should also be taken into account.

The use of a smaller boat towed by the bigger vessel to carry the transducer helps to detect fish which are frightened by the vessel.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Limitations of echo sounders

Sound beam interference by sound scatters eg. temperature stratification, air bubbles, sediments, debris, vegetation
Unsuitable for very shallow depths because of the blind zone that exists a few meters below the transducer depending on the diameter of the transducer and the frequency of the sound waves.

The larger the diameter the larger the zone.
Very deep waters calls for a stronger pulse generating echo sounder

3. Underwater Visual Census Survey (UVCS)

The more traditional method in which diver count fish along transects
It involves an observer, equipped with SCUBA gear, estimating the abundance of fish within a given area (the belt transect).
A multitude of factors, including fish mobility and habitat complexity, have been shown to effect the precision of the counting technique.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Applications of UVCS


Best suited for:
- Reef fish communities
- Shallow coastal waters
- Clear water environments
- Surface schooling species (tuna, sardines)

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Underwater Methods


Belt Transect Method:

Diver swims along fixed transect (e.g., 50 m × 5 m)
Records all fish within belt width
Estimates size classes
Multiple transects per site


Point Count Method:

Diver remains stationary
Counts fish within cylinder (e.g., 7.5 m radius)
Records species, size, abundance
Less affected by fish flight behavior

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Advantages & disadvantages of UVCS


Advantages:

Direct observation
Species identification possible
Behavioral information
Relatively low cost
Good for complex habitats (reefs)


Disadvantages:

Limited to clear, shallow water
Weather and visibility dependent
Observer bias
Diver safety concerns
Small spatial coverage
Fish behavior affects counts

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
4. Catch per unit effort (CPUE)

CPUE is catch obtained per standardized unit of fishing effort
Used as an index of abundance (relative, not absolute)
Catch rate (CPUE) is frequently and single most useful index for long-term monitoring of a fishery

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
4. Catch per unit effort (CPUE)…
Formula:
\[\text{CPUE} = \frac{\text{Total Catch}}{\text{Total Effort}}\]
Effort units:

Fishing hours or days at sea
Number of hooks (longline)
Number of fishers
Number of vessels
Number of gears

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
4. Catch per unit effort (CPUE)…

Changes in CPUE may give an indication of what is happening to the fish stock size
In theory, a constant trend of CPUE values represents a stable stock
A rising trend indicates an increasing stock
Increases in CPUE may mean that a fish stock is recovering and more fishing effort can be applied.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
4. Catch per unit effort (CPUE)…

A falling trend signifies a declining stock
A declines in CPUE may mean that the fish population cannot support the level of harvesting.
However, a falling trend does not necessarily indicate overfishing;

A fish stock will always decline from its initial high level when fishing occurs until it reaches an equilibrium level, when productivity balances the catch being taken.

CPUE can therefore be used as an index of stock abundance

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Advantages & disadvantages of CPUE
Advantages:

Uses existing commercial data
Cost-effective
Long time series available in many areas
Large spatial coverage
Real-time updates possible

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Advantages & disadvantages of CPUE
Disadvantages:

Differences regarding interpretation of fishing effort
Changes in actual or effective effort as a result of technological development
Also influenced by skills, experience
Affected by fisher behavior
May not reflect true abundance
Reporting biases
It is also difficult to know what factors of the fishing operations are important to measure
It is difficult to keep up with fishery changes
eg. CPUE could be altered without it being reflected on the stock size

A boat may install a more powerful motor

Or change from day to night fishing.

Not useful for measuring changes in the stock size of schooling fish species

eg. a pelagic species which schools at the surface can be easily seen from fishing boats or spotter planes therefore can be caught in bulk by purse seine nets.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
5. Mark-Recapture Methods

Is a Relative Fish abundance estimation
It involves capturing, marking, release and recapturing
The basic concept is that;

The ratio of recaptures in the second sample is equivalent to the proportion of those that were marked during the first sampling occasion to the whole population.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
5. Mark-Recapture Methods…

Then, estimation of population size (N) will be;

\[
\frac{m_2}{n_2} = \frac{n_1}{N}
\]

Sample 1 – marked and released

\(n_1\) = number captured and marked on the 1st sampling occasion

Sample 2 - number of recaptures recorded

\(n_2\) = number captured on the second sampling occasion
\(m_2\) = number of recaptures on the second occasion

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Assumptions for mark recapture method

The population is closed so that N remains constant

i.e. there is no movement in or out by birth, death, immigration or recruitment

All the fish have the same probability of being caught
Marked and unmarked fish have equal capture probability
The second sample is a random sample of the population
No marks of fish are lost between the sampling occasions
No marks go unrecorded during the second sampling
Marks do not affect survival

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Advantages & disadvantages of Mark-Recapture


Advantages:

Direct abundance estimate
Provides movement information
Estimates survival rates
Useful for discrete populations


Disadvantages:

Tagging stress and mortality
Tag loss or shedding
Expensive and labor-intensive
Assumption violations is common
Limited to feasible population sizes

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Mark-Recapture: Example 1
Problem:
500 tilapia are captured, marked, and released in Lake Victoria. One week later, 200 fish are recaptured, of these, 25 have marks. Find the population estimate in the lake.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Solution
Using the mark-recapture formula:
\[\frac{m_2}{n_2} = \frac{n_1}{N}\]
Where:

\(n_1 = 500\) (marked fish released)
\(n_2 = 200\) (fish recaptured)
\(m_2 = 25\) (marked fish recaptured)
\(N\) = ??? (unknown population size)

Rearranging the formula to solve for \(N\): \[N = \frac{n_1 \times n_2}{m_2}\] Substituting the values: \[N = \frac{500 \times 200}{25} = 4000\]
The estimated population size of tilapia in Lake Victoria is 4000 fishes.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Mark-Recapture: Example 2
In a capture-recapture process, 200 fishes were tagged. From the capture results, the game warden estimates that, the lake contains 2500 fishes. What percentage of fishes were tagged?

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Solution
Let p be the percent of tagged fishes;
\[
\frac{n_1}{N} = \frac{p}{100}
\]
\(\frac{200}{2500}=\frac{p}{100}\)
\(p = 8\%\)

About \(8\%\) of fishes were tagged

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
6. Depletion Methods

This method is mainly used for shell fish fishery i.e Octopus
The method uses either of the two models i.e Leslie and DeLury methods which depend upon the following assumptions;
Fishing (or sampling) must take a significant proportion of the population causing a depletion

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
6. Depletion method…

The decrease in catch per unit effort is proportional to;

The reduction in the population

Catchability of fish remains constant

Units of effort (or fishing gear) do not compete with one another - remains the same

The entire population is available to the fishery

There is no recruitment, natural mortality, immigration or emigration in the population.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
6. Depletion method…

It involves the removal of individuals from a stock and measuring the resulting decrease in relative abundance using CPUE as an abundance index.
It involves fishing on a closed population in which there is no immigration and emigration
Time interval is short enough to ignore losses due to natural mortality.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
6. Depletion method…
Leslie Method:
\[
\frac{C_t}{f_t} = q(N_o - IC)
\qquad(1)\]
Where;

\(C_t\) = number of fish caught at time t
\(f_t\) = effort expended in taking \(C_t\)
\(\frac{C_t}{f_t}\) = catch per unit effort at time t (CPUE)
\(N_o\) = initial population size
\(q\) = catchability
\(IC\) = accumulated catch

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
6. Depletion method…
Or the Leslie formula can be expressed as;
\[
C_t = qN_0 - q\sum_{i=1}^{t-1}C_i
\qquad(2)\]
Where:

\(C_t\) = Catch in period \(t\)
\(q\) = Catchability coefficient
\(N_0\) = Initial population size
\(\sum_{i=1}^{t-1}C_i\) = Cumulative catch up to time \(t-1\)
Then, plot \(C_t\) vs. cumulative catch; y-intercept = \(N_0\), slope = \(-q\)

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
7. Pelagic Egg and Larval Surveys
Principle:

Sample ichthyoplankton (fish eggs and larvae)
Estimate spawning stock biomass from egg production

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
7. Pelagic Egg and Larval Surveys..
Daily Egg Production Method (DEPM):
\[SSB = \frac{P_0 \times A}{R \times S \times F}\]
Where:

\(SSB\) = Spawning stock biomass
\(P_0\) = Daily egg production per unit area
\(A\) = Spawning area
\(R\) = Sex ratio (proportion female)
\(S\) = Spawning fraction (proportion spawning per day)
\(F\) = Batch fecundity (eggs per spawning female)

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Parameter interpretation
\(P_0\) (Daily Egg Production): Measures spawning intensity in the survey area. Higher \(P_0\) indicates active spawning; reflects reproductive output per unit spawning habitat.
\(A\) (Spawning Area): Geographic extent of the spawning ground. Larger area = greater total egg production. Accurate delineation is critical.
\(R\) (Sex Ratio): Only females produce eggs. Must adjust for proportion of females in spawning population.
\(S\) (Spawning Fraction): Not all females spawn on a given day. Varies by species and environmental conditions. Lower \(S\) = smaller daily fraction of stock spawning.
\(F\) (Batch Fecundity): Individual female reproductive capacity. Higher \(F\) = fewer females needed to produce observed eggs. Critical parameter often determined from histological analysis.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Sample question 1:
A sardine spawning survey in Tanzanian coastal waters collected the following data:

Daily egg production per unit area (\(P_0\)) = 450 eggs/m²/day
Spawning area (\(A\)) = 5,000 km²
Sex ratio (\(R\)) = 0.52 (52% female)
Spawning fraction (\(S\)) = 0.35 (35% spawn per day)
Batch fecundity (\(F\)) = 12,000 eggs/female

Calculate the spawning stock biomass (SSB) of sardine given that each sardine egg weighs ~0.75 mg.

title: AQ 232 – Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Answer:
First, convert spawning area to m²: \[A = 5,000 \text{ km}^2 = 5,000 \times 10^6 \text{ m}^2 = 5 \times 10^9 \text{ m}^2\]
Apply DEPM formula: \[SSB = \frac{450 \times 5 \times 10^9}{0.52 \times 0.35 \times 12,000}\]
\[SSB = \frac{2.25 \times 10^{12}}{2,184} = 1.03 \times 10^9 \text{ eggs}\]
Converting to biomass (sardine eggs ~0.75 mg = 0.00075 g per egg): \[1.03 \times 10^9 \text{ eggs} \times 0.00075 \text{ g/egg} = 7.73 \times 10^8 \text{ g}\]
Convert to tonnes (1 tonne = \(10^6\) g): \[\frac{7.73 \times 10^8 \text{ g}}{10^6 \text{ g/tonne}} = 773 \text{ tonnes}\]
\[SSB \approx 773 \text{ tonnes}\]

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
What is Length-Weight Relationship?
Definition: The mathematical relationship between fish body length and body weight
Key Idea: - Longer fish are generally heavier - But the relationship is NOT linear - Weight increases with the cube of length (cubic relationship) - Different species have different relationships
Why Important: - Convert length measurements to biomass - Assess fish condition and health - Estimate population biomass from length data - Understand growth patterns

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
The Allometric Equation
Standard Length-Weight Formula:
\[W = aL^b\]
Where:

\(W\) = weight (grams or kilograms)
\(L\) = length (centimeters or millimeters)
\(a\) = intercept (scale factor)
\(b\) = slope (exponent, typically 2.5-3.5)

Logarithmic Form (for linear regression):
\[\log(W) = \log(a) + b \cdot \log(L)\]

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Understanding the Parameters
What does ‘a’ mean?

Scale factor or intercept
Represents the weight when length = 1 unit
Species-specific (different species have different values)
Related to fish condition and body shape
Heavier fish species have larger ‘a’ values

Example: - Nile Perch: \(a ≈ 0.0098\) (robust body) - Cichlid: \(a ≈ 0.005\) (slender body) - Same length, different weight due to different ‘a’

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Understanding the Parameters…
What does ‘b’ mean?

Exponent or slope
Determines how weight scales with length
Typical range: 2.5 to 3.5

b > 3
Allometric growth (positive) - Fish gets proportionally heavier as it grows


b < 3
Allometric growth (negative) - Fish gets proportionally lighter as it grows



Why b ≈ 3? - Volume (and weight) of a 3D object increases with cube of length - A fish that doubles in length becomes ~8× heavier (\(2^3 = 8\))

title: AQ 232: Fish Population Dynamics and Stock Assessment
text:
Isometric vs. Allometric Growth
Isometric Growth (b = 3)

Fish maintains same body shape as it grows
Weight increases exactly with cube of length
Fish becomes equally “robust” at all sizes
Length ratio 2:1 → Weight ratio 8:1

Example: Most fish with uniform body proportions
Positive Allometric (b > 3)

Fish gets relatively heavier as it grows
Becomes more robust/muscular with age
Weight increases faster than cubic relationship
Fish condition improves with size

Example: Nile Perch (b ≈ 3.1)
Negative Allometric (b < 3)

Fish gets relatively lighter as it grows
Body proportions change (e.g., becomes more elongated)
Weight increases slower than cubic relationship
Fish condition declines with size

Example: Some eels, very elongated fish

Estimating Length-Weight Parameters
Step 1: Collect Data - Measure length (L) of fish - Measure weight (W) of same fish - Collect multiple specimens across size range - Minimum 20-30 observations (more is better)
Step 2: Transform Data - Calculate: \(\log(W)\) and \(\log(L)\) - Creates linear relationship for regression
Step 3: Linear Regression - Plot \(\log(W)\) vs \(\log(L)\) - Fit line: \(\log(W) = \log(a) + b \cdot \log(L)\) - Extract slope (b) and intercept (\(\log(a)\))
Step 4: Back-Transform - \(a = 10^{\text{intercept}}\) - Use fitted equation: \(W = aL^b\)

text:
Applications in Fisheries
1. Converting Length to Biomass
Problem: We measure lengths from catches, but need biomass for assessment
Solution: Use length-weight equation - Measure all fish lengths - Apply equation to get individual weights - Sum for total biomass estimate
Example Lake Victoria: - Catch: 1000 fish of various lengths - Use L-W equation to get total weight in kg - Compare to previous months/years

LBSPR and length-based methods need: - Growth parameters (from Von Bertalanffy) - Length distribution (from catch samples) - Length-weight relationship (to convert to biomass)
Without L-W equation, cannot estimate stock biomass from lengths
3. Fish Condition Index

K = 100: Fish in expected condition
K > 100: Fish in better condition (healthier)
K < 100: Fish in poor condition (underfed/stressed)

Indicates nutritional status and environmental health

text:
The length-weight relationship (LWR) remains a fundamental tool in fisheries science for estimating biomass, assessing fish health, and understanding growth patterns. This relationship is mathematically defined by the power law equation:
\[
W = a \times L^b
\]
Where:

 W  = weight of the fish (in grams),
 L  = length of the fish (in centimeters),
 a  = intercept (a coefficient related to the condition factor of the fish),
 b  = slope (an exponent indicating the type of growth).

For easier statistical analysis, the equation is typically converted to a linear form using logarithms:
\[
Log(W) = Log(a) + b \times Log(L)
\]

text:
Growth Patterns Based on the Exponent ‘b’
The exponent b in the length-weight relationship provides insights into the growth patterns of fish. 
The value of b typically ranges between 2.5 and 3.5 in natural environments.

Isometric Growth (b=3): The fish maintains its shape as it grows, with weight increasing in proportion to the cube of its length.
Positive Allometric Growth (b>3): The fish becomes “plumper” or heavier as it increases in length.
Negative Allometric Growth (b<3): The fish becomes “slimmer” or more elongated as it grows.

title: Glossary
text:

Age-Structured Model A stock assessment model that divides the population into age classes and projects each class forward through time, accounting for growth, mortality, and reproduction.




Bycatch Fish species or individuals caught incidentally while targeting other species. Often discarded or of lower commercial value.
Biomass Total weight of all fish in a population or stock at a given time.




Catchability (q) The proportion of the population in an area that is caught per unit of fishing effort. Ranges from 0 to 1.
Catch-per-Unit-Effort (CPUE) Total catch divided by total fishing effort. Used as an index of fish abundance (CPUE = q × Abundance).

Coefficient of Variation (CV) Standard deviation expressed as a percentage of the mean. Used to measure relative variability in estimates.




Discard Fish that are caught but returned to the sea, either dead or alive. Often occurs when catch regulations are exceeded or fish have low market value.

Effort A measure of fishing intensity, including number of vessels, fishing time, gear quantity, or other measures of fishing activity.

Frame Survey A census-based survey that collects data on all fishing vessels, gear, and landing sites to establish a sampling frame and generate raising factors.




Gear Selectivity The property of fishing gear to catch fish of certain sizes more readily than others. Typically expressed as a selectivity curve.
Gonad The reproductive organ in fish. Examination of gonad development determines maturity status.




Harvest Rate The proportion of the population removed by fishing in a given time period (usually annually).

Selectivity Curve A mathematical function describing how gear selectivity varies with fish size.

Stock A population of fish of the same species in a geographic area that shares similar ecological characteristics and is managed as a unit.
